Kay's perspective is so relevant!  I always remind myself that my job is to raise God-fearing, kind, interesting, responsible children.  Children that can look at a "tree" and decide if, when and how to tackle it.

My father's father (who died shortly before I was born, and never once did I ever hear anyone say they missed him) was abusive -- the angry type of belittling, impatient bully. My father never discussed the topic, never got into details -- he didn't have to. I don't feel a loss for not knowing the specifics.The idea that I "should know more" never occurred to me until just now, as I read this article. My grandfather was not a ghost in our household (nor those of aunts/uncles/cousins on that side of the family). Everyone seemed to forget all about him except for a few oft-told anecdotes that comically illustrate his crankiness.

It's important for older kids to understand why their parents struggle with certain kinds of issues, feelings or situations, but not in developmentally inappropriate detail.

I've worked with children of immigrants still struggling with the impact of wars fought decades ago on the other side of the globe. I've also worked with a few children who were displaced by Hurricane Katrina. The kids who know a lot of details seem very burdened. It's like they are supposed to bear witness to their parents' and grandparents' experiences and losses. I don't know that young children are the right people for that job. My husband and his cousins were not told many details of their parents' Holocaust-related immigration experiences until they were young adults.

If the perpetrator of the abuse is around and in your child's life then that's a different story.

Penny, hand on Sheldon's forehead: "Poor dear, you're hot."

Sheldon: "No, I have an elevated body temperature."

Penny: "What's the difference?"

Sheldon: "Well, if we had the same temperature our heat content would depend on our respective mass. What do you weigh?"

Penny: "Good luck finding soup. Goodbye."

"Nerve" is a better word than "electrical" for this impulse in most contexts, but not in a crossword clue for NEURON.

It is true that a calorimeter is required to measure heat, however one of the components of the calorimeter is a temperature measuring device which is usually usually a thermometer. So, if one knows the heat capacity coefficient for a given substance, the change in the amount of heat (i.e. energy) in the substance is proportional to the corresponding change in its temperature. One therefore can use thermometers to measure changes in heat content.

As a crossword puzzle clue, this is quite OK.

Some sloppy science in this puzzle. Spoiler alert.................................

A thermometer does not measure Heat. The instrument which measures heat is a Calorimeter. A thermometer measures temperature, which is not the same as heat.

The preferred term is NERVE IMPULSE, rather than electrical impulse. Even though it is electrical (involving charged particles, not electrons) in nature, it is quite different from electric current travelling in a wire.

Another example; this whole health care reform is a centrist action. What most of us liberals wanted, and still would prefer, is a single payer system. By following the Republican model for universal health care, relaying on private insurance companies, Obama took the middle ground, as he had to to get passage of the bill.

It's disheartening, but not surprising, that Republicans are talking about the current legislation exactly as they would a single payer system, if that had passed. "Greatest ever expansion of government", etc. But more disheartening and still somewhat surprising (I know, I know, I'm naive) is when pundits like Mr. Friedman also use the same language to discuss the situation as they would if single payer had passed. Et tu, Thomas?

Very true. But the other thing that really struck me in Mr. Friedman's article was:

"Look at the powerful wave he has unleashed for big, centrist, statesmanlike leadership."

I'm looking at centrist leadership all the time, and I'm certainly not seeing anything remotely resembling a "good" wave from this decision. The Tea Party wants CJ Roberts impeached because he "betrayed them." The liberals are moaning about how he butchered the Commerce clause.

What this decision has proved beyond a doubt is that the only thing being "centrist" gets you is an attack from both sides of the isle. Which is exactly what's happening to Mr. Friedman's centrist politician, Barack Obama - except he's also being attached from the center.

Mr. Friedman, I think Prof. Krugman was referring to you when he wrote on his blog:

"By now, the centrist dodge ought to be familiar. A Very Serious, chin-stroking pundit argues that what we really need is a political leader willing to concede that while the economy needs short-run stimulus, we also need to address long-term deficits, and that addressing those long-term deficits will require both spending cuts and revenue increases. And then the pundit asserts that both parties are to blame for the absence of such leaders. What he absolutely won’t do is endanger his centrist credentials by admitting that the position he’s just outlined is exactly, exactly, the position of Barack Obama."

You complain about the lack of leadership, but the fault is in yourself. We have a leader. You need to start listening to him.

Even the Medicare Trustees do not believe that the savings attributed to Medicare are likely to occur. For example, they assume that Congress will continue to prevent reductions in physician reimbursement rates, as they have done for many years with annual Doc Fix legislation.

As they say in their the 2012 report outlining two "Illustrative Alternate Scenarios": "Medicare’s actual future costs are highly uncertain and are likely to exceed those shown by the current-law projections in this report. Therefore, the Board recommends that readers interpret the current-law projections as an illustration of the very favorable financial outcomes that would be experienced if the physician fee reductions were implemented [etc.]"

https://www.cms.gov/Research-Statistics-Data-and-Systems/Statistics-Tren...

William M: "Private health insurance with community-rated premiums and guaranteed issue, with government subsidies toward insurance premiums paid by individuals on a means-tested basis."

I took this as a reference to employer-sponsored insurance, which continues under the ACA and thus could be considered part of it. The employer tax exclusion could certainly be called a "means-tested subsidy toward insurance premiums", although the "means-testing" is the reverse of what we usually expect.

I do remember your all payer system. As I recall you cited Maryland, which is at the top of the charts in the Dartmouth Atlas. Hardly a viable proposal for bending the cost curve or increasing value of sick care spending.

I must say it was quite clever to call the bill the Affordable Care Act. It's a shame that the title has nothing to do with the contents of the legislation -- perhaps Congress' attempt at irony.

What an odd characterization of the Unaffordable Care Act in bullet 2 of Professor Reinhardt's post. That is a description of the Emmaneul/Fuchs plan or the bipartisan Ryan/Wyden plan – it’s not the Unaffordable Care Act. Medicare, Medicaid, and employer-based health insurance are now “Private health insurance with community-rated premiums and guaranteed issue, with government subsidies toward insurance premiums paid by individuals on a means-tested basis.”?

Also interesting that in his bullet 2 he chose not to characterize the Unaffordable Care act as “tax financed” which of course it must be if it is “government subsidized.” Even a lowly SCOTUS justice could figure that out. And a regressive tax at that.

It is interesting to follow this blog over time. As an Economist, Professor Reinhardt told us we needed sick care reform in order to bend the cost curve. When it became clear that the Unaffordable Care Act would increase sick care costs, he gave up that line of discussion and became a Social Philosopher. Sort of a reverse Adam Smith. Perhaps one day he will return to the topic of costs and explain how the Unafffordable Care Act is going to decrease sick care costs as a percent of GDP.

I haven’t seen any proposals from either party advocating the libertarian alternative Professor Reinhardt has described. He must have been watching the current POTUS who characteristically says “some people suggest” and then makes up something that no one has ever suggested.
